III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section Program statement
Description (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
1

(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth possessing contraband and staff failing to act
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was contacted via phone on 8/13/2025.
Complainant did not provide any additional information.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the hospital on
8/14/2025. Youth A reported staff check youths belongings and do
a search when they return to the facility. Youth A reported that
some time ago another youth who is no longer at the facility tried
to bring back a vape and staff confiscated it from her. Youth A
denied being aware of staff not addressing youth bringing
contraband to the facility.
Program Manager and Supervisor were interviewed face-to-face
at the facility on 8/14/2025 and on 8/22/2025. Program Manager
and Supervisor reported when youth return to the facility they are
checked in which includes their belongings being searched and
body searched. Program Manager and Supervisor reported the
body search includes use of a detector wand and youth are asked
to empty their pockets, lift their hair if it is tied back, and to shake
their clothing including their bra in case items are being snuck in.
Program Manager and Supervisor reported if youth do manage to
get something in the building they are not supposed to have it is
addressed immediately and taken from the youth. Program
Manager and Supervisor did not recall a recent incident of this
occurring in the facility.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/14/2025.
Staff 3 reported youth do sometimes attempt to bring things they
cannot have such as vapes to the facility which staff find when
checking them in. Staff 3 reported they are confiscated from the
youth at that time. Staff 3 reported if it is suspected a youth has
gotten something past check in they will search rooms and
belongings. Staff 3 was not able to recall a recent time contraband
was found after check in. Staff 3 reported Youth A attempted to
bring a vape back once and it was found during check in and
confiscated. Staff 3 was unsure how long ago this incident
occurred.
2

Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 4, Staff 5, Staff 6 were each interviewed
separately face-to-face at the facility on 8/14/2025 and via phone
on 9/16/2025. Staff did not have any knowledge of any youth
bringing contraband including vapes into the building and staff not
addressing the situation. Staff reported all youth get checked back
in when they return and this includes their belongings being
searched and a search of their person with a detector wand. Staff
each reported youth shake out their hair and clothing during the
check.
Youth B, Youth C, Youth, D, and Youth E were each
interviewed separately face-to-face at the facility on 8/22/2025.
Youth reported staff check youth for contraband including vapes
when they get to the facility. Youth reported youth get their things
checked and are searched with a detector wand. Youth reported
the youth also have to shake their hair out and clothing. Youth
reported youth get a consequence if they try to sneak something
in. Youth denied knowing about any youth having things they were
not supposed to have and staff not doing anything about it.
Documents reviewed:
• Contraband Policy prohibits any cigarettes, lighters,
candles, incense, aerosol cans, nail glue, fireworks, drug
paraphernalia, possession of stolen goods, weapons
(knives, guns, razor blades, or anything with the potential to
puncture, cut, scratch or gouge to cause serious injury are
considered weapons), cell phones, pagers, violent or illicit
reading material, prescription / non-prescription drugs,
street drugs and alcohol.
• Search Procedure states upon arrival to the facility youth
will have their belongings searched. Search Procedure
states youth may be asked to empty their pockets upon
return to the facility.
Analysis There are no rule violations established regarding this allegation.
It was consistently reported by staff and youth there is consistent
search occurring when youth return to the facility. It was
consistently denied any youth had brought in contraband and staff
failed to address it.
Consultation
It is recommended the facility add specific steps and means youth
are searched into their search procedure including the use of the
detector wand and having youth loosen their clothing and hair.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
3

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4138
Section Bedding and linen
Description (2) Each resident shall be provided with clean sheets and a
pillowcase at least weekly and more often if soiled.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth do not have access to clean clothing and bedding
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was contacted via phone on 8/13/2025.
Complainant did not provide any additional information.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the hospital on
8/14/2025. Youth A reported always having clean clothing and
bedding at the facility. Youth A reported some youth might have
their blanket taken if they were on observation.
Program Manager, Supervisor, Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4,
Staff 5, and Staff 6 were separately interviewed face-to-face at
the facility on 8/14/2025, 8/22/2025, and via phone on 9/16/2025.
Each employee reported youth always have clean clothing and
bedding at all times. Each employee reported their washing
machine was down over the weekend so laundry was taken to a
laundromat and no youth went without clean bedding or clothing
during that time frame.
Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E each were interviewed
separately face-to-face at the facility on 8/14/2025 and 8/22/2025.
Each youth reported having clean clothing and bedding at all
times. Each youth reported they had clean clothing and bedding
even when the washing machine was broken over the weekend.
No youth expressed concern regarding access to clean clothing or
bedding.
Documents reviewed:
• Linen and Laundry Policy states youth are responsible for
their laundry unless there is a health concern at which time
staff will assist. Policy states if new or additional items are
needed to see the residential treatment worker for
assistance. Policy states laundry must be done weekly.
Analysis No rule violation is established regarding this allegation. All youth
and staff consistently reported youth have access to clean clothing
and bedding.
Consultation
4

It is recommended the facility include language on circumstances
in which a youth’s bedding may be confiscated, such as suicidal
observation into their precautionary watch policy.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section Health services; policies and procedures.
Description (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth are not receiving their mental health services
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was contacted via phone on 8/13/2025.
Complainant did not provide any additional information.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the hospital on
8/14/2025. Youth A reported she would ask to make doctor’s
appointments and they would not get made. Youth A reported she
was supposed to have therapy weekly and would often not be
able to have her appointment. Youth A could not recall how often
she did have therapy or how many appointments were missed.
Youth A reported the facility was going to find her a new therapist
but did not do that. Youth A reported the therapist would cancel
the appointment sometimes. Youth A reported she did not get her
physical scheduled and is in need of dental fillings. Youth A was
not certain how long she has been waiting for these appointments.
Youth A reported needing an OB appointment and it not being
scheduled.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/22/2025.
Staff 1 reported scheduling for Youth A’s therapy and medical
appointments was not a consistent concern. Staff 1 reported
Youth A had weekly therapy consistently up until Youth A got a job
and it created a scheduling conflict with her therapist as Youth A
was no longer available during the week for sessions. Staff 1
reported she was working to find Youth A a new therapist and it
had been a couple of weeks since determining the schedule was
not going to work with her old therapist. Staff 1 reported efforts
were being made since 7/31/2025. Staff 1 reported the case
manager, whom Staff 1 identified as Staff 4 is tasked with
scheduling appointments for the youth in the facility and would
5

know more specifics on any other appointments for Youth A
including dental, a physical, and OB. Staff 1 denied any
awareness of Youth A having issues getting necessary medical
and dental appointments. Staff 1 reported being aware Youth A
was in need of dental fillings and was awaiting DHHS to work
something out regarding her braces.
Program Manager and Supervisor were each interviewed face-
to-face separately at the facility on 8/22/2025. Each denied
awareness of Youth A struggling to get needed appointments
including therapeutic, medical, and OB. Each reported DHHS was
working on a matter with Medicaid regarding Youth A needing
fillings because she has braces and steps and approvals were
needed for that process.
Staff 2, Staff 5, and Staff 6 were interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 8/22/2025 and via telephone on 9/16/2025. Each denied
awareness of issues for Youth A having therapy, medical, dental,
or OB appointments.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/22/2025.
Staff 3 denied awareness of issues for Youth A having therapy,
medical, dental, or OB appointments. Staff 3 reported Youth A did
have to change her therapy schedule when she obtained a job
however was not aware that she was not still getting regular
therapy.
Youth B, Youth C, and Youth E were each interviewed face-to-
face separately. Each youth denied having challenges getting their
therapy, medical, or dental appointments completed while at the
facility. Each youth denied being aware of any other youth having
issues getting their needed appointments scheduled or being
taken to them.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/22/2025.
Youth D denied being aware of any youth having trouble getting
their therapy, medical, or dental appointments at the facility. Youth
D reported she has a rash on her wrist and she has been waiting
to go. Youth D reported she has an appointment scheduled this
week. Youth D could not recall how long she has had the rash or
been asking to go to the doctor.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/22/2025.
Staff 4 reported the barrier for Youth A’s dental fillings was that
she had braces and they needed DHHS to complete steps with
Medicaid in order to get the appointment and that the team was
working on it. Staff 4 reported the therapist had scheduling issues
6

following the appointments being moved to Saturdays and they
were working on finding a new therapist.
Documents reviewed:
• Email authored by DHHS Foster Care Specialist noting
Youth A was current on her medical and dental
appointments. Email confirms barrier to receiving dental
fillings is due to her orthodontia. Email states there were no
concerns with the facility in scheduling and accommodating
for therapeutic services.
• Medical Appointments and Individual Therapy policies
states youths’ therapeutic, medical, and dental needs will
be met while at the facility.
Analysis There is no rule violation established regarding this allegation. It
was consistently reported by staff and youth medical, therapeutic,
and dental appointments are made and completed for the youth at
the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section Intervention standards and prohibitions
Description (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iii) Threats of restraint, seclusion, punishment, or otherwise
suggesting physical or emotional harm to a youth.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff verbally threatening youth
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was contacted via phone on 8/13/2025.
Complainant did not provide any additional information.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the hospital on
8/14/2025. Youth A reported Staff 6 threatened her when Youth A
said in a joking manner to Staff 6 to “hold on” and Staff 6
responded asking who the hell Youth A thinks she is and calling
Youth A a bitch. Youth A reported Staff 6 also said she bet Youth
A would not punch her. Youth A reported she ended the
altercation by walking away from Staff 6. Youth A denied anyone
else being around during the exchange.
7

Program Manager, Supervisor, Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4,
Staff 5 were interviewed separately on 8/14/2025 and 8/22/2025.
Each denied observing any employee use any threatening
language with any youth including with Youth A. Each denied
observing any staff use curse words with youth.
Staff 6 was interviewed via telephone on 9/16/2025. Staff 6
denied using or hearing other staff use threatening language with
Youth A or any other youth at the facility. Staff 6 denied calling
Youth A a bitch or saying “I bet you won’t hit me.”
Youth B, Youth C, Youth D and Youth E were each interviewed
face-to-face separately. Each youth denied staff cursing at them
or other youth. Each denied any staff using threatening language
with them or to any other youth at the facility.
Documents reviewed:
• Behavior Management Policies & Practices states corporal
punishing including slapping, pinching, and holding are
prohibited. Policy prohibits verbal abuse including swearing
and cursing at youth.
• Training Record for Supervisor documents 27.5 hours of
training including verbal de-escalation and mandatory
reporting.
• Training Record for Staff 3 documents 27.5 hours of
training including supportive adult training.
• Disciplinary Action for Staff 3 dated 8/22/23 regarding
leaving youth unsupervised.
• The Role of Staff Member states staff should never be
inappropriate with youth in any manner.
• Human Resources file for Staff 6 details zero disciplinary
actions and 25 hours of training including Supportive Adult
and Verbal Crisis De-Escalation.
Analysis A rule violation is not established regarding Allegation #1. Staff
and youth denied staff threatening youth or cursing at youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4162
Section Seclusion within secure and nonsecure facilities; seclusion plan;
Description prohibitions; reduction and elimination.
8

(1) An agency must establish a process improvement and a
seclusion reduction/elimination plan that addresses the following
areas:
(ii) Conflict management.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth being locked in a room or area
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was contacted via phone on 8/13/2025.
Complainant did not provide any additional information.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the hospital on
8/14/2025. Youth A reported she and other youth at the facility
have been locked in the stairwell before. Youth A reported youth
would go into the stairwell when they wanted to have a second to
themselves if they were worked up. Youth would ask to go in there
but staff would leave them in there and not let them back in. Youth
A reported staff would claim there was a door to get outside but if
that door was used youth would get in trouble and be considered
AWOL. Youth A reported staff started to put a chair in the door so
they were not shut in but staff still would let them back inside right
away when they wanted to come back in. Youth A reported almost
all the youth at the facility had been locked in the stairwell at one
point or another. Youth A reported Youth B and Youth C have
been locked in the stairwell before.
Program Manager, Supervisor, Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4,
Staff 5 and Staff 6 were each interviewed separately on
8/14/2025, 8/22/2025 and via telephone on 9/16/2025. Each
reported youth ask to go into the stairwell to calm down and came
back out when they knock. Each reported youth know they need
to be calm down to come back out so if they are not calm and
banging on the door they are told they need to calm down further
before they can come out. Each reported there is an emergency
exit. It was reported the alarm would sound and youth would be
considered AWOL for exiting out the emergency exit.
Youth B, Youth C, Youth D and Youth E were each interviewed
face-to-face separately. Each reported youth are allowed to go
into the stairwell and ask to do so. Each denied it being used as
punishment. Each reported youth have to be calm to come back in
and sometimes they are not as calm as staff want them to be let
back in right away so they pound on the door. Each reported there
is an emergency exit but they get in trouble if they use it.
9

Documents reviewed:
• Behavior Management Policies & Practices states corporal
punishing including slapping, pinching, and holding are
prohibited. Policy prohibits verbal abuse including swearing
and cursing at youth. The policy does not mention a
prohibition of seclusion.
• Training Record for Supervisor documents 27.5 hours of
training including verbal de-escalation and mandatory
reporting.
• Training Record for Staff 3 documents 27.5 hours of
training including supportive adult training.
• Disciplinary Action for Staff 3 dated 8/22/23 regarding
leaving youth unsupervised.
• The Role of Staff Member states staff should never be
inappropriate with youth in any manner.
• Human Resources file for Staff 6 details zero disciplinary
actions and 25 hours of training including Supportive Adult
and Verbal Crisis De-Escalation.
Analysis A rule violation is established regarding this allegation. It was
consistently reported by youth and staff youth have been in the
stairwell and not let back into the hallway right away until they
were called.
Technical Assistance:
The facility should revise their behavioral management policy to
include language defining and prohibiting seclusion.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
